dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so today, we're diving into what it really means to be a *great* leader, not just a good one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so today, we're diving into what it really means to be a great leader, not just a good one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, it's more than just managing, right? The article describes it as "next-level management."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, it's more than just managing, right? The article describes it as next-level management.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Think of leadership as next level management.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's taking those expert management skills and, um, combining them with people skills to really shine.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's taking those expert management skills and, um, combining them with people skills to really shine.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The best leaders take their expert management skills and combine them with people skills to become well rounded and highly successful.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the biggest difference, it says, between good and great, is all about the relationships you build with your team. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the biggest difference, it says, between good and great, is all about the relationships you build with your team. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The difference between being a good leader and a great one is in the relationships you build with your team.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And one of the key components is this idea of "coaching, not directing." Like, you're a teacher, a mentor, not, uh, a dictator.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And one of the key components is this idea of coaching, not directing. Like, you're a teacher, a mentor, not, uh, a dictator.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Coaching, not directing. A great leader is a teacher and a coach, not a dictator.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right! Not just telling people what to do. It's about helping them grow, supporting them, nurturing them, but also knowing when to give them that push.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Not just telling people what to do. It's about helping them grow, supporting them, nurturing them, but also knowing when to give them that push.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They help their teams develop and grow, and support them by providing training in various forms, including coaching and mentoring. They understand when they need to nurture their teams, and when they need to push them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, you know, understanding that everyone's different. There's no one-size-fits-all coaching style. You gotta, like, experiment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, you know, understanding that everyone's different. There's no one-size-fits-all coaching style. You gotta, like, experiment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be a great coach, you must understand that everyone has different needs and that there isnt a one size fits all solution. Learn how your team members work best, and tailor your coaching to match their work style. When youre responsible for very large teams, its much more difficult to know which style will work best, so its best to experiment with a few styles until you find the one that gets the desired results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which leads us right into being "adept," doesn't it? Being ready for change at any moment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which leads us right into being adept, doesn't it? Being ready for change at any moment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Being adept. Great leaders are prepared for change to happen at any time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Great leaders are, um, quick thinkers. They can make decisions fast and, more importantly, rally their team to get results even when things shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Great leaders are, um, quick thinkers. They can make decisions fast and, more importantly, rally their team to get results even when things shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theyre able to think and make decisions quickly, and more importantly, they know how to rally their teams to make results happen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And paying attention to both the process *and* the people, that's crucial. You ignore one, and the other just, like, falls apart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And paying attention to both the process and the people, that's crucial. You ignore one, and the other just, like, falls apart.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a leader, you have to be very aware of everything thats happening from a process standpoint as well as a people standpoint. Paying equal attention to both is important. By ensuring that your team is performing to the best of their abilities, youll be better able to keep the process on track. If you ignore one, the other will suffer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Next up, it's all about respect. It's a two-way street, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Next up, it's all about respect. It's a two-way street, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Respect. Respect is a two way street, and it must be given to be had in return.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the article really hammers home that micromanaging is, uh, one of the quickest ways to lose respect. It shows you don't trust your team.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the article really hammers home that micromanaging is, uh, one of the quickest ways to lose respect. It shows you don't trust your team.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No employee likes to be micromanaged, as it indicates to them that you don't trust their abilities. In fact, its one of the quickest ways to lose respect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, allow them to take risks, even fail sometimes. And, um, be willing to roll up your own sleeves and jump in when needed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, allow them to take risks, even fail sometimes. And, um, be willing to roll up your own sleeves and jump in when needed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Leaders must allow their employees to take risks and accept that they will fail sometimes. ... The best leaders have no problem working alongside their employees and arent afraid to roll up their sleeves and jump in to help the team when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And finally, becoming a master communicator. This one is huge for me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And finally, becoming a master communicator. This one is huge for me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Being a master communicator. Great leaders can tailor their communication style to meet the needs of any situation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Being able to tailor your communication style to any situation, and more importantly, being an excellent listener.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Being able to tailor your communication style to any situation, and more importantly, being an excellent listener.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders can tailor their communication style to meet the needs of any situation. A leader must be an excellent listener, in order to truly understand the needs of their team.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, understanding those different communication styles â€“ listening, advising, directing, motivating... it's, uh, so important to switch between them seamlessly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, understanding those different communication styles - listening, advising, directing, motivating... it's, uh, so important to switch between them seamlessly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are six key communication styles you should be familiar with - listening, advising, directing, motivating, teaching, and coaching. Each one has it's own place and time to be used, and are most effective when combined. Being adept in your communication methods is absolutely necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Practice, practice, practice! It's all about practice to master that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Practice, practice, practice! It's all about practice to master that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To master the art of communication, you simply need to practice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, whether you're a manager or not, these are skills anyone can, like, work on to be a better leader.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, whether you're a manager or not, these are skills anyone can, like, work on to be a better leader.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No matter what your title is, you can become a leader. Practice these skills, and you'll be on the path to great leadership.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. You wanna be a great leader? Start with these.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. You wanna be a great leader? Start with these.
